DhÄraá¹‡Ä«-holder!
What is meant by the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's correct observation and selection of the aggregate of consciousness?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes that the aggregate of consciousness is not an aggregate, it is an aggregate of delusion, it is an aggregate of falsehood.
Why is this?

DhÄraá¹‡Ä«-holder!ğŸ”½This aggregate of consciousness arises from delusion, is bound by false conditions, exists due to past karma, is bound by present conditions, belongs to various causes and conditions, is false and nonexistent, arises from conceptual discrimination, arises from consciousness, and is called consciousness because there is something that is cognized.
It arises from conceptual discrimination, conceptual thought, and observation, exists provisionally, and is called consciousness because there is something that is cognized.

Because it cognizes things, because it gives rise to mental activities, because it thinks, because it arises from various conditions, because it gives rise to various thoughts, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.
From the cognizable, the image of consciousness emerges, demonstrating mental activity, subsuming thought, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.

Sometimes called mind, sometimes called thought, sometimes called consciousness, all are categorized by the aggregate of consciousness, demonstrating the characteristics, functions, and nature of consciousness, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.

Thus, the non-aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness, unborn, unarisen, uncreated, but by corresponding with inverted views and falsely cognizing conditions, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.
Why is it so?

This aggregate of consciousness arises from various causes and conditions, without self-nature, arising in sequence, moment by moment, arising and ceasing, this consciousness condition does not give rise to the characteristics of the aggregates.
Why is it so?
The characteristics of the arising of this aggregate of consciousness cannot be obtained, and its definitive characteristics also cannot be obtained.

Because the characteristic of arising cannot be obtained, because the definitive characteristic cannot be obtained, because the fundamental does not exist, because the intrinsic characteristic does not exist, and because the firm and solid cannot be obtained, the wise one correctly observes, selects, and penetrates that which is not the aggregate of consciousness is the aggregate of consciousness.

The foolish person generates the characteristic of the aggregate of consciousness in that which is not the aggregate of consciousness. By conceptual thought, discrimination, and inverted attachment to false thoughts, he falsely binds and forcefully names it the aggregate of consciousness. He is attached to this aggregate of consciousness and relies on what is cognized. Because he relies on the various manifestations and contemplations of consciousness, the aggregate of consciousness arises.

This person discriminates in various ways, being attached to internal consciousness, attached to external consciousness, attached to internal and external consciousness, attached to distant consciousness, and attached to near consciousness. Because of the characteristic of consciousness, he discriminates and generates the aggregate of consciousness.
This person, by conceptual thought and discrimination, borrows the false names of mind, thought, and consciousness, and thus knows the various characteristics of mind that arise.

These ordinary beings are attached to the aggregate of consciousness, bound by the aggregate of consciousness, and because of the combination of mind, thought, and consciousness, they give rise to various aggregates of consciousness.

Because of discriminating false phenomena, because of the single characteristic, and because of the definitive characteristic, they are able to discern and become attached to this mind, this thought, and this consciousness.

These people, relying on the aggregate of consciousness and deeply craving consciousness, are able to obtain the aggregate of consciousness of the past and become attached to the thought of existence, are able to obtain the aggregate of consciousness of the future and become attached to the thought of existence, and are able to obtain the aggregate of consciousness of the present and become attached to the thought of existence.

Among the dharmas of seeing, hearing, feeling, and knowing, ordinary beings grasp and obtain the aggregate of consciousness and become attached to the thought of existence. These people, attached to the dharmas of seeing, hearing, feeling, and knowing, are bound by the aggregate of consciousness. They value their knowledge and are bound by the combination of mind, thought, and consciousness, thus running and coming and going.
That is to say, from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world, all because they are bound by the aggregate of consciousness.

They are unable to truly understand the aggregate of consciousness. The aggregate of consciousness is false, unreal, and associated with inverted views. It arises based on the dharmas of seeing, hearing, feeling, and knowing. There is no real consciousness here.

If one is unable to truly contemplate in this way, one may give rise to wholesome consciousness, unwholesome consciousness, or both wholesome and unwholesome consciousness. Such a person always follows the activities of consciousness, does not know the source of the arising of consciousness, and does not know the true characteristics of consciousness.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should contemplate in this way: They should know that the aggregate of consciousness arises from false consciousness, that is to say, it arises from the various causes and conditions within the dharmas of seeing, hearing, feeling, and knowing. Because of the notion of the arising of dharmas where there are no dharmas, they become attached to the aggregate of consciousness.
We should not follow the study of ordinary people. We should truly contemplate and discern consciousness. We should truly contemplate and discern the aggregate of consciousness.

When these bodhisattvas contemplate in this way, they realize that the aggregate of consciousness is false and unreal, and from the beginning it has always been the characteristic of non-arising. They know that what is not an aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness, the reflected image aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness, and the illusory aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness.
It is just like a person created by an illusion; consciousness is not within, not without, and not in between. The nature of consciousness is also like this;

Like the nature of an illusion, it arises from false conditions, from memory and discrimination, without any real substance, like a mechanical wooden person. Consciousness is also like this, arising from the inversion of false causes and conditions coming together.

When contemplating in this way, one realizes that consciousness is all impermanent, suffering, impure, and without self. The characteristics of consciousness are like an illusion, and the nature of consciousness is contemplated as like an illusion.
At that time, the bodhisattva thinks like this:

'The world is extremely deluded, namely, arising from the conceptual discrimination of consciousness, it arises in the world, and combines with the mind and consciousness. The three realms are all just consciousness. This mind and consciousness also have no form and no direction, not within dharmas and not outside dharmas.

Because ordinary beings are bound by the corresponding false characteristics, they become attached to the aggregate of consciousness as either a self or what belongs to a self. This person becomes attached to the aggregate of consciousness within, attached to the aggregate of consciousness without, attached to the aggregate of consciousness within and without, attached to the aggregate of consciousness in others and in themselves. This person values this aggregate of consciousness, is bound by the aggregate of consciousness, experiences the taste of the aggregate of consciousness, and speaks of the characteristics of the aggregate of consciousness, namely, the mind, the thought, and the consciousness. Because they follow the taste and act, they become attached to experiencing the aggregate of consciousness. This person is bound by consciousness, because the aggregate of consciousness combines, they are dragged along by the mind, consciousness, and thought.

Because of the power of the causes and conditions of mind, thought, and consciousness, ordinary beings are born. If they give rise to inferior thoughts, they obtain an inferior body; if they give rise to superior thoughts, they obtain a superior body; if they give rise to middling thoughts, they obtain a middling body. This person is born according to the power of mind, thought, and consciousness, relies on the sense bases, and because of attachment to the aggregate of consciousness, does not escape birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.

' The Bodhisattva, in this regard, correctly contemplates and selects the aggregate of consciousness as it truly is. Because he correctly contemplates the impermanent characteristics of the aggregate of consciousness, he does not crave or cling to past aggregates of consciousness, and knows that what is not an aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness.
He also does not crave or cling to future aggregates of consciousness, and knows that what is not an aggregate is the aggregate of consciousness.
He also does not rely on present aggregates of consciousness.
He correctly knows the impermanent characteristics of the aggregate of consciousness, and correctly knows the characteristics of the arising and ceasing of the aggregate of consciousness.
If one contemplates and correctly observes the aggregate of consciousness in this way, this is called correctly observing the path of entering the aggregate of consciousness.

Namely, truly knowing consciousness, truly knowing the arising of consciousness, truly knowing the cessation of consciousness, and truly knowing the path to the cessation of consciousness. This person truly observes the arising and cessation of the aggregate of consciousness, can destroy the aggregate of consciousness, can cut off all characteristics, and knows the arising and cessation of the aggregate of consciousness, and also penetrates the arising and cessation of the aggregate of consciousness.

At that time, the bodhisattva neither gives rise to the aggregate of consciousness, nor extinguishes the aggregate of consciousness. This aggregate of consciousness has been unborn from the beginning. When observing in this way, one does not discriminate the characteristics of the cessation of consciousness, and penetrates the unborn characteristics of the aggregate of consciousness.
Why is it so?
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!

This aggregate of consciousness is unborn, without characteristics, and without formation. The nature of the arising of this aggregate of consciousness is false, and thus enters into the characteristics of non-arising.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
The aggregate of consciousness is ultimately without the characteristics of formation and arising. The characteristics of this aggregate of consciousness arise from various causes and conditions.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the Dharma of dependent origination in this way. It is not the aggregates that are consciousness, but the observation and selection of the aggregate of consciousness. They believe and understand, realize and penetrate, knowing all consciousness to be ultimately real.
Because bodhisattvas know the ultimate reality of the aggregate of consciousness, in this way all objects of cognition are known to be destroyed.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the aggregate of consciousness in this way, knowing that this aggregate of consciousness is unborn, without an agent, without arising, without a receiver, and without anything received. It arises only through various conditions, and because various conditions come together, there is bondage due to conditions of seeing, hearing, cognition, and consciousness. From the beginning, it is always ultimately empty.

When contemplating the aggregate of consciousness in this way, one immediately knows that the aggregate of consciousness is the characteristic of non-action and non-arising, and does not value or cling to it.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate and select in this way to enter the aggregate of consciousness.

If bodhisattvas can skillfully enter the five aggregates in this way, and can skillfully contemplate the five aggregates in this way, this is called penetrating the arising, cessation, and path of the five aggregates, and being able to eliminate all the characteristics of the aggregates, and truly understanding the skillful means of the five aggregates.

By means of these skillful means, within the five aggregates of clinging, one is not greedy, attached, bound, or fettered, and truly knows the characteristic of impermanence of form. If there is defilement and attachment to form, a bodhisattva is then able to eliminate it;

and also truly knows feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, and also truly knows the characteristic of impermanence of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness. If there is defilement and attachment to feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, one is then able to eliminate it.

Because bodhisattvas eliminate defilement and attachment within the five aggregates of clinging, they accord with and penetrate the skillful means of the five aggregates, and when contemplating in this way, they are able to know the subtle arising and ceasing characteristics of the five aggregates of clinging.
Dhá¹›á¸hatara,
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas being able to observe and select the subtle arising and ceasing characteristics of the five aggregates of clinging?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe sentient beings, when they first enter the womb and are in the kalala stage, the five aggregates cease first and then there are again five aggregates that arise.

From this point on, they observe the arising and ceasing of the five aggregates. Although the previous consciousness ceases, they also know that the five aggregates are not a state of annihilation. Although the consciousness relies on the kalala, they also know that the five aggregates are neither reaching nor permanent.

Thus, they observe the arising and ceasing of the five aggregates of conditioned existence in a single thought when first entering the womb. From the kalala stage up to birth, and later as they grow until the time of death, they observe the arising and ceasing of the five aggregates of conditioned existence in each moment of thought. In this way, they observe and discern the subtle arising and ceasing of the five aggregates of conditioned existence.
Dhá¹›á¸hamati!

The subtle arising and ceasing of the five aggregates of conditioned existence means that the previous five aggregates of conditioned existence cease, and in sequence there is nothing that reaches the womb. When the consciousness first combines, the five aggregates immediately have arising and ceasing. Based on the five aggregates of conditioned existence in the kalala stage, it is provisionally named a person.
Why is it so?
Dhá¹›á¸hamati!
If consciousness has no support, it cannot abide. The five aggregates are the support of consciousness.
Dhá¹›á¸hatara,
Moreover, the subtle arising and ceasing characteristics of the five aggregates of the gods in the formless realm should also be known in this way.
Dhá¹›á¸hatara,
Such subtle arising and ceasing characteristics of the five aggregates cannot be reached by the wisdom of pratyekabuddhas, let alone the wisdom of Å›rÄvakas.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, up to the realm of the wisdom of the Buddha, although they observe and discern the subtle characteristics of the five aggregates from the initial entry into the womb up to the formless realm, they still cannot thoroughly understand them as known by the Buddhas.

The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, do not have wisdom that follows others. They naturally attain all wisdom and skillful means, and attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
The wisdom of the buddhas penetrates everywhere. The unobstructed wisdom of the buddhas attains definitive wisdom in all dharmas, and attains the power of mastery over all dharmas.

All ordinary beings are unable to contemplate the five aggregates in this skillful way, let alone contemplate the subtle arising and ceasing of the five aggregates.
Why is this?
Because ordinary beings are unable to know the five aggregates as they really are. Ordinary beings do not know grasping, and do not know the aggregates of grasping.
Dhá¹›ti!
What is called grasping?

Grasping refers to grasping at self, grasping at sentient beings, grasping at views, grasping at precepts and observances, grasping at the five aggregates, grasping at the eighteen elements, and grasping at the twelve links of dependent origination. This is called grasping.

Up to all dharmas, whether internal or external, such as grasping at desire, grasping at existence, grasping at seeing, hearing, knowing, and perceiving, and grasping at self and what belongs to self.

Ordinary beings, in regard to this false grasping, do not know or see, and due to inverted causes and conditions, grasp at all dharmas. This person is bound by grasping, and due to the causes and conditions of ignorance, grasps at formations. Formations, due to the causes and conditions of consciousness, grasp at consciousness. Consciousness, due to the causes and conditions of name-and-form, grasps at name-and-form. The coarse characteristics of name-and-form are that sentient beings become attached and take refuge.
Namely, grasping at form, combining with form, being bound by form, and grasping at the four formless aggregates. Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are distinguished as name.

If there were no buddhas, sentient beings would have nothing to know and nothing to see, and would be unable to correctly contemplate the five appropriated aggregates.

'I will rely on this and thereby attain happiness.'

This person, with this thought of happiness, craves and returns to the five aggregates, with the thought of suffering and the thought of neither suffering nor happiness, craves and returns to the five aggregates.

Since birth, ordinary people are blind and do not know what the five aggregates are, do not know where the five aggregates come from, and do not know the five aggregates as they really are. Therefore, they greedily accept the five aggregates, and for this reason they are called the aggregates of grasping.
Who is the grasper in this?

The grasper here cannot be found. It is only because of the deluded attachment to falsehood and self-binding due to ignorance and delusion that one grasps at self, grasps at what belongs to self, and grasps at this and that. Therefore, it is said that the aggregates of grasping are the five aggregates, and there is no grasper, nor any definite characteristic.

Therefore, the wise know that the five aggregates of grasping are not the aggregates, the aggregates of grasping are the five aggregates of grasping, and the aggregates of ignorance are the five aggregates of grasping. Ordinary people are bound by this and greedily return to the five aggregates of grasping.
Because of greedy returning, they do not know what grasping is.
What are the aggregates of grasping?
But because of attachment, they return to the five aggregates, transmigrating through birth and death. Because of attachment to these five aggregates, they run through the various destinies.
What do they return to out of attachment?

They return to views out of attachment, they return to hearing out of attachment, they return to cognition out of attachment, they return to consciousness out of attachment, they return to craving out of attachment, they return to ignorance out of attachment.

These ordinary beings, bound by the bonds of craving, are attached to the five aggregates of clinging, covered by the hindrances, entering the darkness of ignorance, not knowing, not realizing, 'To what do we now return out of attachment?
Where are we bound?'

Because of not knowing, they transmigrate through the realms of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods, bound by birth and death, returning to birth and death out of attachment, not letting go, not abandoning, not cutting off the five aggregates, and also not able to know the true characteristics of the five aggregates.
Because of not knowing them as they really are, they are harmed by various sufferings and afflictions, falling into the prison of emptiness without knowing the way out.

Because this person does not see the path of liberation, he undergoes birth and death in the path of beginningless birth and death, and therefore cannot attain liberation from birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress, nor can he cross the perilous path of immeasurable birth and death, nor can he escape the great mass of suffering. He returns to and reverts to suffering, becomes attached to suffering, and is controlled by suffering.
What is suffering?
The five aggregates of clinging are suffering. When they arise, they are merely suffering arising; when they cease, they are merely suffering ceasing.

I teach the Dharma to my disciples for this reason.

For this reason, I say the world disputes with me, but I do not dispute with the world.

It refers to those who are attached to the five aggregates of clinging. They are included in the world. These people are attached to the five aggregates and are bound by the five aggregates.
They do not know the nature of the five aggregates, nor do they know the empty characteristics of the five aggregates, yet they argue with me.
These people go against the Buddha's words and argue with the Buddha, and therefore fall into great distress.

If there are people who, whether the Buddha is in the world or after the Buddha's extinction, are able to contemplate in this way that the false five appropriated aggregates are empty and nonexistent, arising from the darkness of inverted ignorance, and are deceptive false thoughts that only deceive ordinary beings, not the five aggregates but resembling the five aggregates, then such people do not argue with the Buddha, do not go against the Buddha's words, and therefore escape the suffering of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts.

The Buddhas do not argue with people. To be called a Buddha is to sever all disputes. They only expound the true Dharma for sentient beings, saying:
'You all!
What you have previously grasped are all inversions. Due to the power of inversions, all sentient beings greedily return to the five aggregates and come and go in the world.

This person, having already returned to the five aggregates, gives rise to various wrong views, returns to various names and forms, and returns to various worries, sorrows, and afflictions. Only the Buddha can save him.

Because ordinary people have a small mind and little wisdom, they crave the five desires and rely on the five aggregates with many faults. This ordinary person, together with the savior, the one to return to, the one to rely on, and the one who delivers from all worries and afflictions, disputes.

I now raise my hand. Those who see the five aggregates, see the characteristics of the aggregates, and are attached to the five aggregates, I do not take them as my disciples. Such people are the followers of non-Buddhists, namely those who give rise to the characteristics of the five aggregates and are attached to and take refuge in the five aggregates.

In the future, in the final five hundred years when the Dharma is about to perish, those who leave the household life in my Dharma will mostly be those who give rise to the characteristics of the five aggregates, who definitively speak of the characteristics of the five aggregates, who are deeply attached to the five aggregates and enter into false and deviant paths, who have left the household life in my Dharma, who wear the kasaya around their necks, and who always enjoy going to and fro in the homes of laypeople. Know that such people are no different from non-Buddhists, and that they will also use my Dharma to be respected and offered to by many people.

Therefore, DhÄraá¹‡Ä« Holder!

When constantly contemplating correctly, the defilements of desire within the five aggregates of clinging can then be eliminated, and one can also attain such skillful means in the profound Dharma.
